metadata.synopsis: Default Dialogue - the conversation you can have with Minthara at any thime when she's a member of your party. You can ask her about herself, or events that you've experienced together during your adventures. Her responses to you may differ based on some of the choices you make after she joins. Provided you don't betray her for another, she will continue to stand by you, revelling in the violence that follows.

20.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
20.text: I do not often doubt myself, but surviving Orin took courage and strength I was not sure I had.
20.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

177.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
177.text: I do not often doubt myself, but surviving Orin took courage and strength I was not sure I had.

140.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
140.text: I could not have faced her without you.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: Few people could face a Chosen of Bhaal. You did.

42.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
42.text: You are trying to raise my spirits. I appreciate it, but any joy the sight of Orin's corpse brings me is but a speck of comforting shade.

131.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
131.text: There is little relief to be found from the heat of the storm we are caught in.

176.speaker: Player
176.text: Our fight isn't over yet. Not while Gortash still stands.

143.speaker: Player
143.text: Our fight isn't over yet. Not until we confront the elder brain.

52.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
52.text: Correct. I am glad that you see things as I do - no matter what victory we have won, we cannot afford to relax our guard.

132.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
132.text: While the brain is still free, and we are still infected, we will never be safe.

47.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
47.text: But we can talk of this later. For now, let us be glad that we still draw breath. And that Orin does not.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: You have your vengeance. How does it feel?

111.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
111.text: Like a dream half-realised. Our fight is not done.

21.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
21.text: The tadpole you harvested is not a curiosity to be pickled and studied - it is a weapon that can unlock the potential of our own parasites.
21.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

157.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
157.text: The tadpole you harvested is not a curiosity to be pickled and studied - it is a weapon that can unlock the potential of our own parasites.

77.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
77.text: If you will not use it, give it to me.

172.speaker: Player
172.text: Given your hatred of the cult, I thought you might want to avoid the tadpoles.

3.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
3.text: Good. When I am stronger, we are stronger.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: It's mine - I'll do as I wish with it.

145.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
145.text: All I ask is that you do not waste it.

31.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
31.text: I see the change in the shimmer of your skin, and hear it in the hum of your blood. You are evolving.
31.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

119.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
119.text: I see the change in the shimmer of your skin, and hear it in the hum of your blood. You are evolving.
119.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

5.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
5.text: You absorbed a tadpole's essence to accomplish this change. Do you have more?
5.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

154.speaker: Player
154.text: Given your hatred of the cult, I thought you might want to avoid the tadpoles.
154.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

85.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
85.text: Free of the Absolute's influence, the tadpole is a boon. It has expanded my mind, and improved my body.

117.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
117.text: I am no longer simply its host - I am its mistress.

127.speaker: Player
127.text: Yes, I have another in my pack. You're welcome to it.
127.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

128.speaker: Player
128.text: The parasites are rare - I'm not sharing them.
128.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

14.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
14.text: All I ask is that you do not waste them.

190.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
190.text: If you ever hesitate to indulge your illithid potential, remember that I will not.

66.speaker: Player
66.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

124.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
124.text: If you discover any, do share. When I am stronger, we are stronger.
124.context: NodeContext: End of this branch of conversation. After this line it jumps back to a ton of unrelated questions

101.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
101.text: Ink and paper are not as insidious as the voice of the Absolute, but they send out their commands all the same.
101.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

55.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
55.text: Ink and paper are not as insidious as the voice of the Absolute, but they send out their commands all the same.

18.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
18.text: Think this, feel that, hate them.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: The people aren't gullible enough to believe everything they read.

168.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
168.text: Is that so? I suppose it explains why they allowed a tyrannical servant of Bane to take control of their city.

153.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
153.text: Perhaps it is why they will allow us to rule in his place when the time comes.

158.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
158.text: Is that so? I suppose that is why they have allowed a tyrannical servant of Bane to take control of their city.

54.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
54.text: Truly, the citizens of Baldur's Gate are a model of shrewd wisdom that we should all hope to emulate.

106.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
106.text: Yes. I am surprised the house matrons of Menzoberranzan have not discovered the power of the printing press yet.

28.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
28.text: Paper spun from spider-silk, Everdark ink drawn from dragon scales, and nefarious lies dreamt in darkness.

182.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
182.text: To kill one's enemies with a well-rounded phrase... that is true power.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: If you controlled the Mouth, what would you have it say?

83.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
83.text: I would use the Mouth to ensure the people did not trust one another. Suspicion creates doubt, and doubt creates dependency.

62.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
62.text: And they would know that they could depend on me. Feared, venerated, adored. I would be everything to them.

116.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
116.text: I agree. They should offer them shelter from the danger that is coming.
116.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

49.speaker: Player
49.text: I agree. They should offer them shelter from the danger that is coming.

94.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
94.text: I was not suggesting they be allowed to roam free. They should be put to work - the city needs labourers, and fodder to protect it.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: Are you suggesting they be used as slaves?

175.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
175.text: I am suggesting they be fed and sheltered, and that they work in return. Call it whatever you wish.

63.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
63.text: Perhaps you think it would be better for them to starve or be slaughtered here, while the citizens hide behind their walls?

2.speaker: Player
2.text: It's only fair that they should earn their keep.

32.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
32.text: Yes. And if they work hard enough for long enough, the city might allow them to earn their freedom one day.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: They'd be better off seeking help elsewhere if all they can hope for here is to die for Baldur's Gate.

41.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
41.text: If they are weak, they will die, whether it is on the road or in the defence of the city. And if they are strong, they will find a way to survive.

179.speaker: Player
179.text: I'm surprised to hear you suggesting aid for those in need.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: They're not the city's responsibility - the patriars have right to turn away anyone they wish.

29.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
29.text: I do not disagree. But to turn them away would be wasteful.

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Indeed. They could be a convenient source of food if the city falls under siege.

110.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
110.text: Hmmm. The weak and the elderly perhaps.

147.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
147.text: The young would be better used as a labour force than as a source of nutrition.

144.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
144.text: That is your gift to me, and we are bound together until it is done.
144.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

126.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
126.text: That is your gift to me, and we are bound together until it is done.
126.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

76.speaker: Player
76.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

84.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
84.text: Perhaps longer, if you wish it.

9.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
9.text: This bond we share... I believe it is alurlssrin. If that is so, it will last as long as we do.

96.speaker: Narrator
96.text: *Alurlssrin. It is a word used rarely, describing the deepest bonds of trust and love.*

99.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
99.text: While Orin lives, I fear we will not last long at all, whether together or apart. We must find her, and kill her.

125.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
125.text: You see a future for us once our enemies are dead? I am not so sure.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I hope our bond will last beyond that.
121.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

134.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
134.context: NodeContext: alurlssrin - deep love, drow language

90.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
90.text: What we share is no more than ssinssrigg, a passion that burns fierce, but has no foundation.

93.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
93.text: It may become more - I hope that it does - but it may also become the cold ash that follows the flame. Or another story written in scars.

129.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
129.text: Whatever the case, it will be a short story if Orin has her way. We must find her, and kill her.

192.speaker: Player
192.text: In that case, the sooner we kill Orin the better.
192.context: NodeContext: played just debuffed her romantically - she's hiding the fact she's upset

92.speaker: Player
92.text: Then the sooner get our vengeance, the better.
92.context: NodeContext: played just debuffed her romantically - she's hiding the fact she's upset

91.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
91.context: NodeContext: played just debuffed her romantically - she's hiding the fact she's upset

24.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
24.text: When we first met - before Moonrise - I intruded on your thoughts without hesitation, and took what I needed from your memories.

107.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
107.text: I would not do that again unless I had reason to think you were hiding something from me. And I do not.

10.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
10.text: I did not think we would ever share anything more than an uneasy alliance, born of our mutual enmity for the Absolute.

183.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
183.text: I was wrong. A deeper bond has grown between us.

25.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
25.text: But I would like to touch your thoughts again, now that my mind is my own. May I?

173.speaker: Player
173.text: Only if I can see your thoughts as well.

48.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
48.text: Of course. I do not hide anything from you.

130.speaker: Player
130.text: Why the sudden interest in my thoughts?

50.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
50.text: When the Absolute fell silent, I thought I would be alone. I expected to spend my days among surface-dwellers who knew nothing of my culture.

16.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
16.text: I did not expect to meet one still sworn to Lolth who would understand me.

148.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
148.text: I have been told that I am special since my mother first held me in her arms. The burden of expectation.

167.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
167.text: You should be. On those rare occasions when people have surprised me in the past, I received new scars to remember them by.

142.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
142.text: You are different - a pleasant surprise. One of the first in my long life.

35.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
35.text: Before the Absolute, I lived a life of certainties. I knew that I was destined for greatness because I was born to it.

187.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
187.text: I also knew that my inherited privilege came with a cost - that the bonds of fellowship and family could be broken by envy and ambition.

95.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
95.text: I could not enjoy the taste of food for fear of poisoning, and I could not enjoy the company of lovers and friends because I feared they hid knives behind their smiles.

15.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
15.text: In spite of the danger, I was happy. I knew myself, and I understood the world around me.

178.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
178.text: Without Lolth, without the Absolute... without my home. I do not know myself. But you do, I think.

67.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
67.text: Show me myself through your eyes - let me see what I am to you.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: Open your mind - let her in.

102.speaker: Narrator
102.text: *She joins her thoughts with yours, and you are as one. You share in her strength of mind and formidable will, but also the doubts that eat at her conviction.*

81.speaker: Narrator
81.text: *Those doubts cluster in swarms, and the thickest is around her sense of self. She pushes past, revealing the image of her you hold in your mind.*

115.speaker: Narrator
115.text: *The cold shell of Minthara's mind melts away, and you are drawn into the heart of her - warm, passionate, and dangerous.*

163.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
163.text: I have never lacked confidence, but this conflict seems so much bigger than the two of us... it frightens me. I do not know if we will survive it.

8.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
8.text: But whatever life remains to us, I would gladly spend it fighting at your side. And lying with you at night.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: That would be a good life.

73.speaker: Narrator
73.text: *Her mind touches yours, feather-light and hesitant. A stark contrast to the confidence with which her thoughts intruded on yours in the past.*

174.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
174.text: Tonight there will be no voices, no orders, no gods... I belong only to you.

160.speaker: Player
160.text: We should focus on the fight.

159.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
159.text: As you wish. It is a rare occasion when I do not get what I want - but you have shown your worth in many ways.

105.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
105.text: I will be satisfied to have you as an ally.

1.speaker: Narrator
1.text: *Her mind cools - acceptance is coloured by disappointment.*

33.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
33.text: We need one another as allies, but I want more from you than that. I want all of you.

150.speaker: Player
150.text: We fight side by side. That is enough.

112.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
112.text: Now you can have me instead.

164.speaker: Player
164.text: No. I don't want to leave them.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: That's what I want. I'll let them know.

162.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
162.text: We need to trust one another if we are to survive, but I want more from you than that. I want all of you.

155.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
155.text: We are both survivors. But I hoped you saw me as more than that.

17.speaker: Narrator
17.text: *A flicker of warmth had spread from her mind to yours - it is snuffed out in an instant.*

46.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
46.text: If I must be a greater monster than the Absolute to survive it, then I shall be. Perhaps one day, if you survive too, you will realise that I had no choice.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: I'd prefer to just tell you.

59.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
59.text: Even honest words can obscure meaning. Thought and feeling are pure, without artifice.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: No. You need to figure this out for yourself.

45.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
45.text: I do not think anyone can be the mirror to their own soul, and even if I could, it is your view of me that I want to see.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Stop this. I'm not your mirror.

152.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
152.text: Fine. Perhaps it is for the best that your thoughts stay hidden. I may not know what I am, but I know what I want.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: You wouldn't enjoy seeing what I think of you.

149.speaker: Player
149.text: Bad idea. You wouldn't like what you saw.

180.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
180.text: Then perhaps you are right to keep it from me. I may not know what I am, but I know what I want.

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: I do not need to like myself - and you need not like me either - for us to exact vengeance on those who infected us.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: I understand you well enough, but I don't like you very much.

88.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
88.text: Then I have misunderstood you, and myself.

104.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
104.text: Go. We will not speak of this again.

169.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
169.text: I did not expect to meet another outcast from the Underdark who understood me.

89.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
89.text: Until my time in the cult of the Absolute, I had spent little time on the surface, except to raid and pillage.

98.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
98.text: I did not expect to find any outside the Underdark who saw the world as I do, and wanted from the world what I want.

137.speaker: Player
137.text: If you trust me, why do you need to poke around inside my head.

13.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
13.text: I do not need to - I want to. You fascinate me.

138.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
138.text: When we first met, I did not think we would ever share anything more than an uneasy alliance, born of our mutual enmity for the Absolute.

23.speaker: Player
23.text: We need to set some rules about tadpole usage.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: I felt you, peering into my mind. What are you hoping to find?

109.speaker: Narrator
109.text: *At first she seems to invite you inside, but then a coldness settles across your mind like morning frost, and you lose contact with her.*
